reviewText: I grew up watching the old 'singing cowboy' movies.  If you are looking for a bit of nostalgia this will fit the bill.  There is also the "comfort" factor.  They bring back memories of going to the local movie theatre on a Saturday afternoon.  You would usually go with friends and then walk home afterwards and talk about what a great movie it was...even if it wasn't.  Back then I would have a coke with my popcorn...today, at home, I can have something a little stronger with the popcorn.  Good movies.
As this was a gift it is hard to review and rate..He seemed to enjoy in his last days. Thanks

Being a city girl, I didn't know what to expect out of these cowboy movies.  But I found them to be very likeable.  I checked this collection out of my local public library.  The first movie in the set features Rex Allen and has actually a fairly complex plot.  And the movie featuring Gene Autry, while simplistic, nonetheless is likeable too.  The overall goodness of the lead characters gives these movies a refreshing charm that is lost nowadays.  And by the way, the voices of these cowboys are remarkable.  Very impressive.  They sing with the full voice but with soft expression.  These movies are appropriate for family viewing.  And they are just plain fun.
DVD listed as having the 71 minute version of Gene Autry's "The Big Show".  This is the 54 minute version.

If you like the old western movies before technicolor, this DVD is for you.  Ah, life seemed so simple--the good guys win and the bad guys lose, and the good guys sing along the way.  There's even a bit of comic relief.  This DVD is good if you need to get a different (better) perspective on life, too.  Life doesn't have to be as complicated anad full of stuff as we make it.

VCI Entertainment present "CLASSIC WESTERNS COLLECTION: THE LEGENDARY SINGIN' COWBOYS FOUR FEATURE" (234 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- now in Glorious Black and White --- VCI presents four outstanding films in the genre of the Western --- relive those thrilling days from the early '30s and '40s when Gene Autry, Roy Rogers, Rex Allen and Eddie Dean took us down the dusty trails with some of the best B-Westerns ever to grace the Saturday Matinee Screen --- just remember double the thrills, mystery and suspense --- hitting the bull's eye with excitement --- don't miss any of these B-Western features loaded with action that will leave you wanting more --- Excellent cast of fine actors with Mary Ellen Kay, Slim Pickens, June Vincent, Smiley Burnette, Kay Hughes, Sally Payne, Max Terhune, Lynn Roberts, Raymond Hatton, Roscoe Ates and Richard Cramer --- outstanding directors William Witney, Mack V. Wright, Joseph Kane and Ray Taylor takes the helm of each oater.

The first of four Classic Westerns - "COLORADO SUNDOWN" (Released: 8 February 1952) (67 mins/B&W) --- Our story line, Rex Allen is suspicious and writes to the Forestry Department, when Dusty Hurley (John Daheim) states that all the trees are infected and must be cut down --- as the Hurley Lumber Company has killed the forester and Dusty in now in his place --- can Rex help Slim Pickens and clean up this mess before the last reel --- The last and certainly one of the better singing cowboys, was Rex Allen --- featuring Koko, the Miracle Horse, Mary Ellen Kay, Slim Pickens, June Vincent and Fred Graham,

SPECIAL FEATURES:
BIOS:
Rex Allen
Date of Birth:  31 December 1920 - Willcox, Arizona
Date of Death:  17 December 1999 - Tucson, Arizona

Second feature - "THE BIG SHOW" (Released: 16 November 1936) (71 mins/B&W), Our plot line, Gene plays a dual role, one a bad-tempered film star cowboy and his good-natured stunt double --- at the beginning the stunt double fills in for the star at a public appearance, with numerous complications arising from the fact that Autry gets many opportunities to sing, plus there are also some good action sequences ---  light hearted screenplay and entertaining, and it has some good musical numbers plus some comic relief from Smiley Burnette --- Autry uses his likeability for his strengths --- Burnette also gets some good moments, and while the story is mostly used to showcase Autry and the other musical entertainment, the final result is pulling things together --- featuring Smiley Burnette, Kay Hughes,  Sally Payne, William Newell, Max Terhune and Sons of the Pioneers.

BIOS:
1. Gene Autry
Date of Birth: 29 September 1907 - Near Tioga, Texas
Date of Death: 2 October 1998 - Studio City, Los Angeles, California

2. Smiley Burnette (aka: Lester Alvin Burnette)
Date of Birth: 18 March 1911 - Summum, Illinois
Date of Death: 16 February 1967 - Encino, California

In this third feature - "COME ON RANGERS" (Released: 21 November 1938) (57 mins/B&W), the story thus far, Roy and the other Rangers, including his brother, Ken (Lane Chandler) and sidekick, Jeff (Raymond Hatton), receive the news to disband and go home --- once disbanded the outlaws move in to take over, this time assuming the role of peace keepers for a price --- Instead, Roy and Jeff join the cavalry commanded by Colonel Forbes (J. Farrell MacDonald) who just happens to have a beautiful daughter, Janice (Lynne Roberts, aka Mary Hart), who captures Roy's heart --- will Lynne Robert fall for Roy and is there romance in the air when the gunsmoke clears --- good supporting cast Lynne Roberts, Raymond Hatton, J. Farrell MacDonald,  Harry Woods and Lane Chandler,

BIOS:
1. Roy Rogers (aka: Leonard Franklin Slye)
Birth Date: 11/05/1911 - Cincinnati, Ohio
Died: 7/06/1998 - Apple Valley, California

And the final oater - "WILD COUNTRY" (Released: 17 January 1947) (55 mins/B&W), the plot and story line, as U. S. Marshal Eddie Dean takes out after the dirty low-down Rip Caxton (I. Stanford Jolley), who's wanted for the murder of a sheriff and now has his gun-sights set on the dead man's daughter Martha Devery (Peggy Wynne) --- but don't touch that dial, Eddie Dean is hot on  the trail and a showdown is about to bring us the final chapter --- featuring Roscoe Ates, Peggy Wynne, Douglas Fowley, I. Stanford Jolley and William Fawcett.

BIOS:
Eddie Dean  (aka: Edgar Dean Glosup)
 Date of Birth:  9 July 1907 - Posey, Texas
Date of Death:  4 March 1999 - Thousand Oaks, Los Angeles, California

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc), Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") and Trevor Scott (Down Under Com) as they have rekindled my interest once again for Film Noir, B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns --- order your copy now from VCI or Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on DVD, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out VCI Entertainment where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns and Serials --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 234 mins on DVD ~ VCI Home Video. ~ (5/29/2007)
This will really take you back to the good old days. Very informative and complete...a must-have for any cowboy fan!
